synthesis Bernhard Herzog, Daniel Herein, Robert SchliSgl * Fritz-Haber-lnstitut der Max-Planck-Gesellschaft, Faradayweg 4- 6, 14195 Berlin, Germany Received 1 August 1995; accepted 18 January 1996 Abstract The formation of the iron species catalysing the synthesis of ammonia was followed by in situ X-ray powder diffraction. It was shown that a complex sequence of reactions during the activation process (reduction of the magnetite precursor) leads to a metastable form of c~-iron. A detailed examination of the diffraction lines of iron helped to elucidate the question, why "ammonia iron" is so much superior to "normal iron". Unusual line profiles were observed which could be controlled by changing the reaction conditions. Platelet crystallites of defective alpha-iron form the outer shell of isotropic bulk iron particles which represent the main body of the catalyst material. A shoulder at higher d values of the Fe(110) reflection points to the formation of an iron/nitrogen phase during catalytic action. The crystallographic observations are in line with previous data on paracrystallinity, but their interpretation is of a different nature. The structural effects of oxygen poisoning were investigated. It is shown, why the poisoning is detrimental for the catalytic performance and how the speculation could arise that this effect may be beneficial for the reaction. Keywords." Ammonia synthesis; Iron; In situ X-ray diffraction; Oxygen poisoning 1. Introduction It is well established that ammonia synthesis is efficiently catalysed by a special form of iron prepared from oxidic precursors [1,2], while ordinary bulk iron is rather inefficient [3]. The significance of structural and electronic promoters was highlighted. But still there is no explanation of the structural identity of "ammonia iron". The turn-over number (TON) of the active site was determined using high-temperature chemisorption of nitrogen on a variety of iron species and was found to be independent on the catalysts nature [5]. The value of the TON points to the presence of C7 sites on (111) or higher indexed surface planes of iron [6]. This is in full agreement with the results from single crystal measurements [7] and indicates that not a principally different chemical property discriminates "ammonia iron" from normal iron but rather a different abundance of active sites. We conclude that this should be reflected in a different microstructure and thus look for average structural differences by X-ray diffraction. The concept of paracrystallinity introduced by Hosemann et al. in 1966 [8] was used earlier to describe the phenomenon of "ammonia iron". They developed the theory of paracrystallinity from X-ray diffraction data which seemed to explain the special properties of the activated iron catalyst [9]. A three-dimensional, endotactic incorporation of hercynite (FeA1204) motives into the a-iron lattice was thought to create substitutional point defects in the crystal lattice leading to a modified bulk and surface structure of the activated catalyst material. The interplanar spacings change and a strain field exists in the vicinity of those defects. Paracrystallinity was defined as the normalised standard deviation of a crystallographic interplanar distance, and it is measured by the width of X-ray diffraction (XRD) lines [10-12]. The explanation of endotactic heterostructures in molecular dispersion for the X-ray anomalies of "ammonia iron" was rejected by MiSssbauer spectroscopy [13] and EXAFS [14,15]. The Mbssbauer data imply the presence of small amounts of non-metal iron components which are present, however, as large particles of structural promoter oxides. They are located in grain boundaries and at the outer surface of the catalyst [ 12,16]. This location also explains the SIMS data on Fe-Al-O fragments which were intended to support the hypothesis of endotactic heterostructures [ 17]. The EXAFS data [ 14,15] provide clear evidence for the identical average local coordination of iron in "ammonia iron" and normal iron. Keeping this large body of information in mind we concentrate on an alternative analysis of the undisputed fact [3] that the line profiles of "ammonia iron" and normal iron are not identical. In the first part we will follow the activation of the catalyst in synthesis gas mixtures starting from an oxidic precursor. Secondly, the average microstructure of the iron catalyst will be discussed using in situ powder diffraction data. In part three we will focus on the structural effects of oxygen as catalyst poison. This work was triggered by recent reports of a potential promoting effect of water/oxygen pulses on the ammonia yield [18]. Bernhar Herzog et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 141 (1996) 71-104 73 2. Either a transformation of the initially formed iron into the active state or surface poisoning of the iron by the still present water from other reaction fronts in the gas phase can explain this finding. Fig. 7 gives an impression of the textural transfor- mations of the precursor. The hypothetical core-and-shell reduction mechanism should result in a constant intensity at temperatures below the reaction onset and to a smooth decay of the intensity with shrinking core which has to be equal for all crystal orientations. This is clearly not the case in the present reaction. In the low-temperature regime of activation (lower than 620 K) the magnetite reorients itself in an anisotropic way. This is qualitatively in full agreement with recent reports about annealing effects on the reduction kinetics of ammonia synthesis catalysts. The fact that different signs in the intensity changes for two orienta- tionally similar diffracting planes were observed points to a migration of defects and a redistribution of sites in the crystals rather than to a change in the volume distribution of the diffracting crystals. General aspects The present work reports data of an in situ observation of the structure of a catalyst during activation and during steady state performance. Modifications of the gas phase composition had direct effects on both catalytic performance and structural parameters detectable by X-ray diffraction. Most of these observations were possible by direct inspection of the diffraction data which were suitable for detailed numerical evaluation due to the operation with internal Si standards and by careful sample movements avoiding geometrical changes of the diffracting material. Based on several direct observation a numerical deconvolution of the Fe(110) reflection gave clear evidence for the presence of several structures of iron which are all long-range order derivatives of bcc iron unit cells. Three Bernhar Herzog et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 141 (1996) 71-104 93 detectable components differ in the defect structure of the diffracting volume. A more precise analysis in terms of orientational anisotropy was not possible due to the present constraints in experimental set-up and the in situ observation conditions. The observations leading to the formulation of the paracrystallinity theory were experimentally confirmed. The analysis in the framework of paracrys- tallinity assumed without proof that only one diffracting phase with molecular homogeneity should be present. In the present work evidence was found by the in situ observation of the influence of the gas phase on the crystal structure of the iron that several structures with different diffraction laws coexist in the activated catalyst. Most spectroscopic methods such as electron spectroscopy, MiSssbauer spectroscopy or EXAFS are too local and sense mainly the existence of unperturbed iron bcc unit cells in the catalyst which is also supported from the present study. X-ray diffraction and methods sampling larger volumes of the reciprocal space such as HRTEM reveal the deviations in long-range ordering which are statistical in their origin and give thus no rise to superlattice reflections. The oxygen-induced restructuring experiment which irreversibly modified the disposition of the different structures within the crystals of iron showed clearly that this second-order effects are very relevant for the catalytic action of the activated iron. The observations of the activation process revealed the importance of the solid state kinetics of the complex process of iron oxide reduction on the formation of the different iron structures. It is shown that the simple picture of a core-and-shell reduction process cannot account for the formation of several iron structures and does not describe the phenomenology of the conversion of iron oxides to the metal as seen by the quantitative analysis of the intensity changes of selected reflections. 4.2. The activation process Our experiments describe the course of events from the precursor to the active phase, a reaction which is influenced in its kinetics by the presence of structural promoters [34]. The main findings can be summarised as follows. The precursor material is chemically inhomogeneous and structurally tex- tured resulting from dissolved aluminium oxide, and ferrous oxide inclusions. Of particular importance is the presence of wuestite (FeO) in the precursor material and during the main reduction process. In the first step of reduction the thermal decomposition of wuestite produces isotropic a-iron nuclei which act as reaction centres for the reduction of the magnetite and set up concentration gradients for iron ions in higher valences. The structural promoters are released from a hercynite-magnetite solid solution phase in the end of the activation process giving rise to an 94 Bernhar Herzog et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 141 (1996) 71-104 inhomogeneous distribution of the exsolution products in the bulk of the catalyst. These exsolution products (either alumina or stoichiometric her- cynite) give stability to the metastable pore system between the iron crystal- lites as they prevent complete contact between the iron particles and hence inhibit Ostwald ripening. The increasing texture of the magnetite phase during activation indicates the formation of non-isotropic iron and documents the mode of operation of a topotactically (spatially anisotropic) controlled reaction kinetics. This kinetics does, however, not reproduce the topography of the precursor oxides as the transportation of all constituting iron ions along low-energy pathways which may not coincide with grain boundaries, is required for the reaction. The reaction kinetics cannot be described by a core-and-shell model [35,34] which would leave the grain structure of the precursor oxide unchanged in the resulting iron metal. Also a modification, the crackling core-and-shell model does not describe the defined and very pronounced change in texture from the oxide to the metal. We observe a restructuring process controlled by the iron ion transport. These findings explain the correct representation of the catalyst synthesis by model experiments with alumina-promoted single crys- tals of (100) and (110) orientations which were activated by an oxidation-re- duction cycle into (111) iron [36]. While topotactic reduction should lead to isotropic dense materials as it is observed for metallurgical magnetite test specimen [37], the active catalyst consists of firmly adhering iron with a defined pore system. The catalyst may be represented by a spongy texture of iron with metallic contacts between the basic structural units giving the whole arrangement a high mechanical stability. From Figs. 6 and 7 it was concluded that the reaction may follow a different route for the promoted catalyst oxide than for metallurgical magnetite. The strong texture of the magnetite precursor which becomes even more pronounced during the activation process offers special directions for the reaction to proceed. While for example the material is preferentially consumed along the (311) plane, (gradu- ally decreasing intensity of the Fe304(311) reflection), the (511) planes seem to act as a substrate for the growth of the anisotropic iron platelets. Fig. 16 displays the different arrangements of iron atoms in both planes. In the (311) plane the atoms are packed more densely than in the (511) plane which may act as transport routes for iron ions. The changing anisotropy of the reacting magnetite crystals indicates that no uniform and isotropic reduction of the precursor occurs and therefore no topotactically related iron particles are formed. The most obvious sign for that is the different lineshape for educt and product displayed in Fig. 4. The structure of the acticated catalyst The basis for the following discussion is a schematic representation [39] of the main structural features of the technical catalyst derived from a variety of Bernhar Herzog et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 141 (1996) 71-104 97 analytical data. The basic idea was that the structure of the active "ammonia iron" is predetermined in the structure of the grains of the oxide mixture. The formed iron particles are separated by a pore system, which increases the active surface of the catalyst and which stabilises anisotropic metastable alpha-iron platelets against sintering by spacers of structural promoter oxides. The thermo- dynamically unfavourable texture of the platelets results in an (111) orientation of the basal planes [40,41], which is known to be very active in the synthesis of ammonia [42,43]. This conjecture of a uniform structure was used in all models of the activated iron catalyst. The heterogeneity of the material was always confined to the composition of iron metal and various oxidic promoter phases. The present findings can be summarised in a model in which an explanation is attempted for the experimental observations of Hosemann et al. The model takes into account the definitive exclusion [3] of endotactic epitaxy [8] as cause for the anomalies. In addition, it should explain, why "ammonia iron" is different in its catalytic action from normal iron. The presence of a preferential orientation in the technical system is the basis for the success of the "single crystal approach" in resolving the mechanism of ammonia synthesis on an atomic scale [44,45]. This fact is further the explana- tion for the at present unique bridge [7,46] between UHV studies [47] and high pressure experiments [48]. We propose that "ammonia iron" is also heterogeneous in the structure of the iron. It is suggested that the diffraction anomalies observed on the bcc iron pattern for ammonia iron are explained by the coexistence of several species of iron crystals which are characterised by different crystal shapes and by different defect structures. Typical defect structures are stacking faults and their ordering and the incorporation of atoms like nitrogen in interstitial sites. Both effects lead to deviations in the exact d spacing of the diffracting planes from which only the (110) orientation was accessible in the present work. Would the defects be present in a defined relative arrangement (ordering) additional reflections due to symmetry lowering of the iron lattice would occur. The complete absence of such a defect ordering leads to a statistical distribution of d spacings with the statistics representing the statistics of the defect ordering. The observed devia- tion in intensity distribution indicates that the basic structural units are not all isotropic. If several types of anisotropic basic structural units coexist or if one type (e.g. platelets) coexist with isotropic basic structural units cannot be decided without additional information. A more complete analysis would require the application of a shorter wavelength such as Mo radiation which was not possible to apply with our presently existing equipment. A spatial anisotropy of the line profile could be used to discriminate these two possibilities. The lineshape of the (110) reflection was used to extract information about two contributions with different d spacing distributions than the main reflection. If the quantitative information from Figs. 6 and 12 are compared we can conclude that the main contribution arises from isotropic bcc iron with no 98 Bernhar Herzog et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 141 (1996) 71-104 significant texture and sizes of the basic structural units of about 70 nm near the instrumental resolution limit. This main part of the material is in nothing different from normal iron and can hardly constitute the active phase of the catalyst. The two other components to the (110) reflection contribute significantly less to the (211) reflection and almost nothing to the (200) reflection and are thus considered as highly anisotropic platelets or dendrites (provided that the inten- sity assignment to the main contribution is correct). The surface normal of the anisotropic structures is thus not parallel to [100]. The internal perfection of one structure is very poor giving rise to an apparent or real small particle size with the centre of the d spacing distribution being at the position of normal bcc iron. We assign a structure of defective iron to it. In the gas phase modification experiments (nitriding and oxidation) the structure was little affected pointing towards a high chemical stability. As interstitial atoms stabilising the defective structure should somewhat affect the d spacing we prefer to assign an internal location within the iron grains to this structure. If the structure is completely surrounded by other compact material it cannot react with different gases and does hence not react to chemical changes in the environment. The internal perfection of the other structure is comparable to that of the main structure but the average d spacing is slightly enlarged. This points to the presence of interstitial atoms. As the abundance of this structure is strongly correlated to the presence of nitrogen in the gas phase (see Fig. 12) we assign an interstitial nitride to this structure. It is pointed out that this analysis is rather crude and more sophisticated methods using Fourier analysis of the line profile do exist. They can, however, only give more reliable information if at least one other reflection with the same quality of counting statistics is available for analysis which is, unfortunately not the case in the present work. For this reason the structural assignment has to remain incomplete at the time and several other structures as suggested in the recent electron microscopy study may well hide behind the complex peak profile which gave rise to the historical paracrystallinity theory. The detection of a distribution of d spacings over a considerable extent (from about 206.6 to 201 pm according to the data in Fig. 9) has further implications on the mechanism of nitrogen dissociation. A recent publication gave evidence that regions of high strain and defect density have a strong influence on the activation of molecular nitrogen [49]. Strained Fe(110) on W(110) proved to be very reactive in the N2 activation and dissociation even at low temperatures. This could imply that the conditions for the structure sensitive nitrogen dissocia- tion found with high-quality unstrained single crystals could also be fulfilled on strained and defective surfaces with other nominal orientations than (111) and (211) irrespective of the presence of alkali promoter species which are known to lift the structure sensitivity. In this way the abundance of the structure with a Bernhar Herzog et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 141 (1996) 71-104 99 high deviation from the bulk Fe(ll0) d spacing could correlate with the catalytic activity even if the main surface orientation of this structure is unknown or not in the directions found suitable with single crystals. In situ diffraction experiments further showed the severe structural conse- quences of limited oxygen poisoning which is not only a surface phenomenon but creates a sequence of bulk reactions. The presence of oxygen leads to a sustained deactivation of the catalyst starting with the formation of isotropic magnetite. This early stage of deactivation causes a marked increase of ammonia production when the surface is enlarged by oxidative etching of the iron grains [3] and nitrogen stored in the iron bulk is released from the overheating caused by the initial oxidation reaction. Addition of oxygen was thought to be a beneficial effect for the synthesis process but the combination of in situ XRPD and reaction monitoring shows that this is only the consequence of a short-term observation [18] of the beginning decomposition of the active phase which is followed by a sustained decreased performance of the catalyst. The exothermic oxide formation also damages the active iron by overheating, which causes sintering of the iron particles. As a consequence inactive a-iron is formed, which is clearly detected in the in situ diffraction pattern (Fig. 14) which also reveals a partial loss of the additional iron structures. These structural observations are in parallel to the changes in the level of catalytic performance shown in Fig. 13. The effects of oxygen poisoning can be eliminated, if the material is quickly reactivated. The typical texture can only in part be restored classifying the poisoning as a structurally irreversible process. 4.4. The structure of the nitride phase The part of the iron structure which changed its abundance in parallel with the nitrogen partial pressure in the synthesis gas atmosphere was associated with a nitride phase. Nitrides of the form Fe4N were already discussed as surface compounds in the literature. It was pointed out that they should be thermody- namically metastable as bulk phase due to the enormous partial pressure of dinitrogen which would be required for their stable formation. On the other hand, the iron-nitrogen phase diagram which was established in the presence of one atmosphere of ammonia shows Fe4N to be stable at the temperatures of technical ammonia synthesis. As under these conditions one atmosphere of ammonia is certainly present in the gas phase over the catalyst, Fe4N could well be the stable form of iron under technical synthesis conditions. We failed to observe the X-ray diffraction pattern of Fe4N in our in situ experiments which is not surprising as we never reached one atmosphere of ammonia during the in situ experiments. Conclusion The microstructural analysis of formation and active state of the industrial iron catalyst for ammonia synthesis has given a new explanation of the old finding about the powder diffraction anomalies. A main new finding concerns the structural inhomogeneity of the iron which is present in several types of basic structural units differing in shape and internal degree of ordering of bcc unit cells which are common to all forms of iron. The analysis revealed one reason for the success of the single crystal approach in explaining the mode of operation on a quantitative basis. The model compound Fe(111) saturated with atomic nitrogen finds its parallel in the technical system by a fraction of anisotropic iron part of which reacts readily with nitrogen to form intercalation nitrides. The main body of the technical catalyst is, however, normal isotropic iron. The non-equilibrium (under ambient conditions) microstructure arises from a combination of a uniquely metastable mixture of precursor oxides and an activation kinetics allowing the topotactic reaction dictated by the iron ion diffusion to control the microstructure of the activated product. The promoters play an essential role not only in stabilising the final structure but also in ascertaining a slow reaction progress in a highly reducing chemical environ- ment. The technologically undesirable fact of a slow activation is the key to the formation of the catalytically relevant minority volume fraction with an unusual microstructure. It remains an open question whether the nitride phase which is the stable form of elemental iron in ammonia atmosphere at elevated temperature is just an unavoidable consequence of thermodynamics or if it affects the course of the catalytic reaction.
